message.content:
"The Fox and the Grapes" is a famous fable attributed to Aesop. In this story, a fox sees some grapes hanging high upon a vine and tries to reach them because he thinks they are luscious. But no matter how much he strains himself, jumps, and stretches his legs, he cannot reach the grapes.

Finally, tired of trying in vain to get the fruit that seems so unreachable for him, he gives up saying: "Oh well! Those grapes are probably sour anyway!". The message being conveyed is that people tend to downplay or discredit things they can't have as if it was never worth having in the first place. This behavior has been named "sour grapes."

This fable teaches us not to be resentful for what we cannot have or achieve but rather accept reality and work harder or look out for other opportunities instead. Furthermore, it exposes how our perspective on something might change when we feel frustrated by our inability to attain it â€“ just like the fox deciding that the seemingly sweet-looking grapes were actually sour simply because they seemed impossible for him to obtain them at that moment.
